definition: v. to become less active, less intense, or less in amount
usecase: As I began my speech, my feelings of nervousness quickly abated.

definition: adj. existing purely in the mind; not representing actual reality
usecase: Julie had trouble understanding the appeal of the abstract painting.

definition: adj. extremely bad
usecase: I got an abysmal grade on my research paper!

definition: adv. in accordance with
usecase: All students must behave accordingly.

definition: n. the act of gaining a skill or possession of something
usecase: Language acquisition is easier for kids than it is for adults.

definition: v. to make suit a new purpose
usecase: The US has adapted many foreign foods to better suit the tastes of Americans.

definition: v. to accommodate oneself to a new condition, setting, or situation
usecase: Dogs are known for their ability to quickly adapt to their environments.

definition: adj. having knowledge or skill (usu. in a particular area)
usecase: Beth loves playing the piano, but she’s especially adept at the violin.

definition: adj. having sufficient qualifications to meet a specific task or purpose
usecase: Though his resume was adequate, the company doubted whether he’d be a good fit.

definition: n. the arrival or creation of something (usu. historic)
usecase: The world has never been the same since the advent of the light bulb.

definition: adj. relating to hostile opposition
usecase: An adversarial attitude will make you many enemies in life.

definition: n. someone who promotes or defends something
usecase: I am an advocate for free higher education.

definition: v. to defend or promote something (usu. a belief, theory, opinion, etc.)
usecase: Environmental protesters often advocate for cleaner energy practices.

definition: adj. relating to beauty or refined taste
usecase: The aesthetic decorations at the wedding reception made you feel as if you were a character in a fairy tale.

definition: v. to be able to buy
usecase: He’s saving money so he can afford to buy a new car.

definition: v. to be able to spare
usecase: I can’t afford to lose any more pencils!

definition: v. to promote something (usu. a cause)
usecase: They’re agitating for better health care.

definition: v. to permit or consent to
usecase: US law allows citizens to speak freely.

definition: v. to make a secretive mention of something
usecase: She alluded to the problem at hand but didn’t say anything more about it.

definition: n. a noisy argument or confrontation
usecase: Greg got into an altercation with a stranger at the bar.

definition: adj. unclear or vague in meaning
usecase: Her ambiguous statement made me question whether she could be trusted.

definition: adj. having a powerful desire for success or achievement
usecase: Penny is so ambitious, she wants to be president someday.

definition: n. the state of being uncertain or stuck between two or more options
usecase: His ambivalence prevented him from immediately signing the contract.

definition: adj. similar but not identical
usecase: Green onions are considered analogous to spring onions.

definition: v. to destroy or cause devastating destruction
usecase: The dictator sent orders to annihilate the group of rebels.

definition: n. something different from the norm
usecase: This result is an anomaly and very rarely happens.

definition: v. assume to be likely to happen
usecase: The party was just as fun as I had anticipated it would be.

definition: n. a strong feeling of dislike
usecase: Her antipathy toward the professor was obvious: she rolled her eyes whenever he entered the classroom.

definition: n. the highest point of something
usecase: The spring play was the apex of our school year.

definition: n. fearful expectation of something
usecase: Her apprehension to leave her house resulted in her missing the train.

definition: v. to clearly express in words
usecase: She articulated her opinion on the price of the house.

definition: adj. something made; not occurring naturally
usecase: Many candies use artificial flavors to make them taste fruity.

definition: n. a strong declaration
usecase: His assertion that sharks are mammals made everyone laugh.

definition: adj. extremely plain
usecase: He lived in a small, austere cabin in the middle of the woods.

definition: adj. stern and forbidding
usecase: My boss had an austere expression on her face.

definition: adj. relating to self-denial
usecase: An austere lifestyle, like that of monks, isn’t for everybody.

definition: n. the quality of being real and true instead of fake and contrived
usecase: The police officer doubted the authenticity of the suspect’s story.

definition: n. an intangible path or approach to something
usecase: The company has decided to pursue other avenues.

definition: adj. actively interested in or enthusiastic about something
usecase: Gerald is an avid soccer fan.

definition: adj. relating to the foundation or basis of something
usecase: You have to start with basic Russian before you can move on to the advanced level.

definition: v. to have as a characteristic
usecase: She bears a strong resemblance to your mother.

definition: v. to have (a child)
usecase: Judy will bear her first child later this year.

definition: v. to bring forth
usecase: My garden is going to bear pumpkins this year.

definition: v. to put up with
usecase: I can’t bear her complaining any longer!

definition: adj. kind, generous
usecase: Many cultures believe in benevolent spirits.

definition: n. a preconception that prevents objectivity
usecase: It’s important to avoid bias when investigating a crime.

definition: adj. tinged with a feeling of sadness
usecase: The ending of the romance movie was bittersweet.

definition: v. to support, strengthen, or fortify
usecase: If we work together, we should be able to lift and then bolster the couch.

definition: n. an increase or growth
usecase: The boost in profits was a welcome change.

definition: v. to increase or make grow
usecase: In order to boost profits, you need to cater to your customers.

definition: n. an intense, loud fight
usecase: A brawl broke out at school today after one student accused another of cheating.

definition: v. to fight loudly and disruptively
usecase: The two students brawled for an hour.

definition: n. the quality of being brief or terse
usecase: The brevity of their time together made it all the more romantic.

definition: adj. direct, blunt
usecase: Josh is candid about his desire to become an actor.

definition: n. the trait of being honest and frank
usecase: I admire her candor, especially when nobody else bothers to speak up.

definition: v. to use to your advantage
usecase: I’d like to capitalize on your math skills by having your work the cash register.

definition: v. to trap or take possession of
usecase: The spy was captured by the enemy.

definition: v. to successfully represent or imitate
usecase: Your painting beautifully captures the ephemerality of life.

definition: v. to captivate, mesmerize
usecase: I was captured by her beauty.

definition: v. to catch or seize
usecase: The cops captured the criminal three days after the incident.

definition: adj. relating to the city or citizens
usecase: Voting is a civic duty.

definition: adj. emotionally unattached (usu. used in medical or scientific setting)
usecase: Her clinical approach to situations allows her to handle them more effectively.

definition: n. special advantage or power
usecase: Children of rich and famous people often believe they have a lot of clout.

definition: adj. indicating a rough texture
usecase: The horse’s mane was coarse, as if it had never been washed.

definition: adj. lacking refinement or sophistication
usecase: The queen’s coarse way of speaking surprised the other members of royalty.

definition: v. to happen at the same time
usecase: It wasn’t until after I booked my ticket that I realized the concert coincided with my finals.

definition: n. the use of payment to request something (e.g., a service or product)
usecase: This painting was commissioned by a rich merchant in 1589.

definition: adj. able to be compared
usecase: This novel is comparable to Huckleberry Finn.

definition: adj. sufficiently qualified
usecase: We need to hire a competent web developer to create a good website for our company.

definition: adj. satisfied, with no desire to change or improve
usecase: Though he had never won any awards or even been published, he was complacent with his life as a poet.

definition: v. to make perfect or complete
usecase: This wine perfectly complements this platter of gourmet cheese.

definition: v. to be forced to agree or surrender
usecase: With no chance of winning the battle, the army at last conceded.

definition: v. to admit to a transgression
usecase: Dan conceded to pranking his sister.

definition: v. to imagine or come up with
usecase: The plan to build the city was originally conceived in the early 1900s.

definition: v. to overlook, approve, or allow
usecase: She couldn't condone her daughter's rebellious behavior.

definition: adj. able to bring about or be suitable for
usecase: The noisy students hardly made the campus library conducive to studying.

definition: v. to control or manage
usecase: The group conducted their research abroad last year.

definition: v. to behave a certain way
usecase: Be sure to conduct yourself accordingly.

definition: v. to share something secretive with someone
usecase: She confided all of her biggest secrets in her best friend.

definition: v. to put limits on; to restrict
usecase: We are going to confine the use of this drinking fountain.

definition: n. overall agreement
usecase: After weeks of debating, the panel finally came to a consensus.

definition: v. to form or compose (part of) something
usecase: The desire for equality constituted the civil rights movement.

definition: v. to think deeply about
usecase: She contemplated telling her teacher about the cheating student.

definition: v. to maintain or assert (an opinion)
usecase: The president contends that the US government will not negotiate with terrorists.

definition: v. to be in contrast with
usecase: The camera footage contradicts his alibi.

definition: adj. highly debatable and causing contention
usecase: Millions of viewers watched the controversial debate take place.

definition: adj. abiding by accepted standards
usecase: She lives a conventional life in the suburbs.

definition: v. to pass on or transfer (information)
usecase: I have trouble conveying my thoughts in French.

definition: n. a firm belief in something
usecase: Her religious convictions prevent her from eating meat.

definition: v. to provide evidence for; to back up (a claim)
usecase: The note signed by her father corroborates her claim that she was absent from class that day.

definition: v. to work in opposition to
usecase: This ingredient seems to counteract the other ones.

definition: n. an argument used to criticize or dismantle another argument
usecase: Make sure to include a counterargument in your essay so that you can show you’ve considered the topic from all perspectives.

definition: adj. hindering the achievement of a goal
usecase: Bill’s idea to take a shortcut was ultimately counterproductive: it took us twice as long to get to the train station.

definition: n. the final act or climax
usecase: The culmination of the performance was unforgettable.

definition: v. to foster the growth of
usecase: Teachers don’t just pass on new information to students—they cultivate their academic potential.

definition: v. to declare formally and with authority
usecase: The president decreed that Halloween would henceforth be a national holiday.

definition: n. respect; regard
usecase: Her deference to the elderly makes her the perfect candidate for an internship at the retirement center.

definition: adj. not enough in degree or amount
usecase: I feel as though the sources for my paper are deficient.

definition: v. to do as an example
usecase: Could you demonstrate the dance move for me?

definition: v. gives evidence for
usecase: This book’s use of words such as “grim” and “bleak” demonstrates the author’s mournful tone.

definition: v. to object to
usecase: She demurred at my request to transfer to a different department.

definition: v. to (over)use over time (usu. resources)
usecase: The lost campers quickly depleted their supply of food.

definition: adj. bare, barren, empty
usecase: The moon is one giant, desolate landscape.

definition: v. to come up with (a plan)
usecase: Lana devised a plan to make herself famous.

definition: n. a problem, usually requiring a choice between two options
usecase: The main dilemma is whether to pay for a commercial or not.

definition: n. conscientiousness; the quality of being committed to a task
usecase: Diligence and confidence will get you far in life.

definition: v. to become smaller in scope or degree
usecase: The itchiness of mosquito bites usually starts to diminish after a few days.

definition: adj. hopeless and dangerous or fearful
usecase: When the police didn’t explain what was happening right away, Jane knew that the situation must be dire.

definition: n. disagreement
usecase: Disputes over money caused intense discord in the family.

definition: n. a lack of respect and strong dislike (toward something or someone)
usecase: He looked at me with such disdain that I immediately knew the job wouldn’t work out.

definition: n. hopelessness, stress, or consternation
usecase: To Nick’s dismay, he got an F on the test.

definition: v. to fill with woe or apprehension
usecase: Many were dismayed by the town’s implementation of metered parking.

definition: v. to belittle or speak down to
usecase: A good boss is stern but never disparages his or her employees.

definition: v. to send off a message or messenger
usecase: The mother dispatched her daughter to their neighbor’s house.

definition: n. the act of becoming diverse
usecase: Lately, there’s been noticeable diversification of students at higher institutions.

definition: n. a principle, theory, or position, usu. advocated by a religion or gov’t
usecase: Devoutly religious people often live their lives according to their doctrines.

definition: n. power and authority (usu. over a territory)
usecase: The country claimed to have dominion over parts of Russia.

definition: n. a legal territory
usecase: Puerto Rico is a dominion of the US.

definition: adj. sad, gloomy, dull
usecase: The gray clouds in the sky made the day feel dreary.

definition: adj. doubtful, questionable
usecase: The man’s claims to the throne were dubious since nobody knew where he’d come from.

definition: adj. peculiar or odd; deviating from the norm
usecase: She’s a little eccentric but still fun to be around.

definition: adj. extremely bad
usecase: After cheating on the exam, Emily began to feel as though she’d made an egregious mistake.

definition: adj. having refined or expressive communication skills (in speaking or writing)
usecase: His speech was not only eloquent but also extremely compelling.

definition: adj. superior or distinguished; high in position or status
usecase: Our town made news when the eminent magician came to perform at our local theater.

definition: v. to discharge, give forth, or release
usecase: Plants consume carbon dioxide and emit oxygen.

definition: adj. very expressive; using emphasis
usecase: Her emphatic smile told me she was excited to ride the roller coaster.

definition: adj. derived from experience, observation, or an experiment
usecase: You need empirical evidence to support your claim.

definition: v. to equip or bestow (usu. a quality or ability)
usecase: According to the myth, the gods endowed him with the gift of healing.

definition: v. to withstand, sustain, or hold out against
usecase: I can’t endure this wait any longer. Will Stanford accept or reject me?

definition: v. to involve or include
usecase: A doctoral program entails long nights and a heavy workload.

definition: adj. firmly established
usecase: Her face will forever be entrenched in my memory.

definition: v. to specify or count
usecase: I can’t enumerate how many times I’ve had to remind my students when their papers are due.

definition: n. excessive jealousy
usecase: His envy of her is quite obvious.

definition: v. to admire and be jealous of
usecase: She envies her coworker's social skills.

definition: adj. having no fixed course; deviating from the norm
usecase: The car became erratic after slipping on ice.

definition: v. to enact
usecase: They established a law that made it illegal to drive after drinking any amount of alcohol.

definition: v. to found (a business, group, school, etc.)
usecase: Our group established a new branch in Chicago.

definition: v. to draw forth or call up
usecase: Horror movies are great at evoking fear.

definition: v. to make worse or increase the severity of
usecase: The doctor told me not to run as it can exacerbate my knee injury.

definition: v. to do something extremely well or to be superior in
usecase: She was a well-rounded student but excelled especially in science.

definition: v. to put into use (usu. as effort)
usecase: Don’t exert all of your energy at once.

definition: adj. invigorating, stimulating, or exciting
usecase: The music playing at the club was catchy and exhilarating.

definition: v. to use up (as in energy or money)
usecase: Be careful not to expend all your energy in the first half of a marathon.

definition: v. to use selfishly or for profit
usecase: The shoddy company exploited its workers by paying them extremely low wages.

definition: v. to aid the progress of
usecase: In grad school, advisors facilitate students’ research and offer constructive criticism.

definition: n. the practicality or possibility of something
usecase: The feasibility of her project was doubtful; she’d have to go all the way to Antarctica and back before the school year ended.

definition: n. viciousness, violence
usecase: The lion is just one wild animal known for its ferocity.

definition: adj. related to (government) money
usecase: Fiscal policy is how the government uses money to influence the economy.

definition: v. to prosper, grow, or make fast progress
usecase: After one year, the tiny plants had flourished into a breathtaking garden.

definition: v. to be unstable; to rise and fall
usecase: Stocks can fluctuate on a daily basis, making it difficult to determine when to buy or sell one.

definition: v. to stir up
usecase: The civilians accused their leader of fomenting political unrest.

definition: adj. capable of being predicted or anticipated
usecase: I can't imagine aliens visiting us in the foreseeable future.

definition: adv. directly, clearly
usecase: I frankly don’t see the point in learning to drive.

definition: adj. carefree
usecase: His freewheeling attitude often got him in trouble at work.

definition: adj. the most essential or most basic part
usecase: A thesis is arguably the most fundamental part of an essay.

definition: adj. thrilling, exciting, stimulating
usecase: The galvanizing performance left everyone spellbound.

definition: adj. relating to old age
usecase: I became interested in geriatric medicine shortly after my grandfather passed away from cancer.

definition: adj. harmful, dangerous
usecase: The voices around the corner sounded angry, hostile even.

definition: adj. supposed; related to a hypothesis
usecase: For my physics homework, I must come up with a hypothetical situation.

definition: adj. publicly shameful or humiliating
usecase: The politician's expensive campaign ultimately ended in ignominious defeat.

definition: v. to transmit, bestow, or disclose
usecase: Parents must impart common sense to their children.

definition: n. the equal and objective treatment of opposing views
usecase: To ensure impartiality, we require everyone to follow these general guidelines.

definition: adj. impressive (esp. in size or appearance)
usecase: The old mansion was imposing in its huge size and gothic architecture.

definition: n. an unnecessary burden
usecase: If it’s not too much of an imposition, could you proofread my paper?

definition: adj. not cautious or prudent; rash
usecase: Backpacking abroad can be fun, but don’t be imprudent about money.

definition: v. to encourage or stir up
usecase: Her hateful words incited anger in the crowd.

definition: n. apathy, emotional detachment
usecase: The girl’s indifference toward her brother upset their parents.

definition: adv. randomly; with little or no distinction
usecase: Lottery winners are chosen indiscriminately.

definition: v. to give into; to satisfy or gratify
usecase: My friend loves to indulge in cheesy romance movies.

definition: v. to guess, conclude, or derive by reasoning
usecase: You can infer from this quotation that the writer didn’t care for “pretty” language.

definition: adj. novel or new (esp. as an idea or invention)
usecase: Her invention was incredibly innovative and won her multiple awards.

definition: adj. can’t be satisfied
usecase: A vampire’s thirst for blood is said to be insatiable.

definition: n. a reversal
usecase: The culture’s norms were an inversion of our own.

definition: v. to call on; to appeal to (e.g., a higher power)
usecase: The shaman attempted to invoke a demon.

definition: adj. incapable of being in harmony or agreed upon
usecase: The couple’s differences were ultimately irreconcilable, giving them no choice but to break up.

definition: v. to feel sorrow for; to mourn
usecase: Susan lamented her missed chance at going to Europe with her high school class.

definition: n. movement
usecase: Physics involves the study of locomotion.

definition: adj. capable of making a lot of money; profitable
usecase: Writing books isn’t a particularly lucrative career, unless you’re J.K. Rowling.

definition: adj. harmful, spiteful
usecase: The malicious spirit drove out the inhabitants from their home.

definition: adj. capable of being molded or changed
usecase: Children’s minds are malleable but only for so long.

definition: adj. superficial; focus on material possessions
usecase: Many people accuse Americans of being materialistic.

definition: adj. extravagant or exaggerated (as of a melodrama)
usecase: The melodramatic play was well liked by the audience.

definition: adj. simple and humble
usecase: They moved into a modest house in the countryside.

definition: adj. small in size or amount
usecase: I received a modest sum of money for my help at the company event.

definition: v. to change, alter, or tweak
usecase: Dr. Nguyen modified the gene so that it wouldn’t carry the disease.

definition: adj. historically significant
usecase: Her win in the election was momentous.

definition: adj. new, innovative
usecase: We are looking for novel ways to approach the project.

definition: n. a subtle difference in meaning
usecase: Body-language experts even understand the nuances of facial expressions.

definition: adj. legally void and ineffective
usecase: The government declared their marriage null.

definition: n. judgment based on observations instead of emotions or opinions
usecase: In scientific research, objectivity is of utmost importance.

definition: adj. no longer used; rare or uncommon
usecase: Historians assumed record players would be obsolete by now, but in fact they’re making a huge comeback.

definition: adj. almighty and all powerful
usecase: Gods are omnipotent beings who can control human destiny.

definition: n. the beginning or early stages
usecase: At the onset of her career as a lawyer, things were looking up.

definition: v. to openly express an opinion
usecase: The new employee opined at the company meeting.

definition: adj. highly detailed and decorated
usecase: That ornate silverware must be worth thousands of dollars!

definition: v. to remove or force out of (usu. a position or office)
usecase: Sick and tired of putting up with his bad moods, the pirates ousted their captain.

definition: adj. predominant, superior, most important
usecase: Our paramount concern is the safety of our employees.

definition: adj. strange, bizarre
usecase: Upon entering the abandoned house, Kate experienced a peculiar feeling, as if someone was watching her.

definition: v. to die; to pass away
usecase: According to the news, nobody perished in the fire.

definition: v. to cause suffering to
usecase: They will persecute anyone who doesn’t agree with their views of the world.

definition: adj. cranky, pouty, irritable
usecase: Petulant children are especially difficult to care for.

definition: n. highest level or degree
usecase: Many believe that composers such as Beethoven and Mozart represent the pinnacle of classical music.

definition: adj. deserving pity
usecase: The frail-looking dog was pitiable, so I gave it some food and took it inside to care for it.

definition: adj. reasonable and possibly true
usecase: Her story is plausible, but that doesn’t mean she’s telling the truth.

definition: v. to assert
usecase: The literary critic postulates that romanticism and naturalism are actually interconnected.

definition: adj. having great influence
usecase: The bald eagle is a potent symbol of the US.

definition: adj. having a strong, chemical effect
usecase: The potion was definitely potent—it healed my wounds immediately!

definition: adj. practical, useful
usecase: It’s not necessarily more pragmatic to study engineering than it is to study philosophy.

definition: n. an example or subject from earlier in time
usecase: This change in law is without historical precedent.

definition: n.  someone who comes before you (usu. in position or office)
usecase: My predecessor gave me many tips for running the office.

definition: v. to command orders
usecase: The directions for our essay prescribe a length of at least ten pages.

definition: v. to issue authorization for medications
usecase: A doctor must prescribe you this medication before you can begin taking it.

definition: n. basic truth, assumption, or rule
usecase: Remember the universal principle: treat others as you want them to treat you.

definition: v. to command against, to outlaw
usecase: Alcohol was prohibited in the US in the 1920s.

definition: adj. punctual, on time
usecase: She is always prompt when it comes to turning in her homework.

definition: n. a cue to begin something; instructions
usecase: I had to write an essay based on a prompt.

definition: v. to incite, propel, or cause to act
usecase: The possibility of a scholarship prompted him to apply to Harvard.

definition: v. to put into law or formally declare
usecase: The ruler will at last promulgate an amnesty with the neighboring countries.

definition: v. to bring criminal action against someone (in a trial)
usecase: The suspect was prosecuted yesterday.

definition: adj. intending to provoke, inspire, or arouse
usecase: Her nude paintings are considered quite provocative.

definition: adj. involving qualities of something (features and content)
usecase: I noticed a qualitative change in her paintings.

definition: adj. involving quantities (numbers and amounts)
usecase: We must conduct a quantitative analysis.

definition: n. a strange habit
usecase: His biggest quirk is his love of old marbles.

definition: v. to split into two or more branches
usecase: Cars ramified throughout the world in the twentieth century.

definition: adj. without attention to danger or risk
usecase: Her rash decision to pass the car nearly resulted in a crash.

definition: adj. unrefined
usecase: He’s got raw talent as a singer, but he needs to work on his performance skills.

definition: adj. not processed; uncooked (as in food)
usecase: In some countries, such as Japan, it is normal to eat raw fish.

definition: adv. right away and without difficulty
usecase: Water was readily available at different points in the race.

definition: n. thinking again about a previously made choice
usecase: The judges’ reconsideration of her performance resulted in her victory.

definition: n. a change for the better; improvement
usecase: The reform made it so that only those 18 and older can legally drive.

definition: v. to improve via change
usecase: The government reformed its vague policies on marijuana use.

definition: v. to prove to be untrue, unfounded, or incorrect
usecase: The student refuted the professor’s claim in class.

definition: v. to strengthen or add support to
usecase: We can use these pipes to reinforce the structure.

definition: adv. somewhat unwillingly
usecase: Max reluctantly agreed to see the horror movie with his friends.

definition: v. to give up (usu. power or a position)
usecase: Our CEO renounced her position yesterday.

definition: v. to cast off
usecase: He renounced his friend after he caught her stealing money from him.

definition: v. to criticize
usecase: The mother reproached her daughter’s school for making students come in during a blizzard.

definition: v. to refuse to recognize as true
usecase: The father repudiated his son’s marriage.

definition: v. to cast off
usecase: She repudiated her son once she found out he’d married someone without telling her.

definition: n. the act of keeping something
usecase: Water retention can make you weigh more on certain days.

definition: adj. satisfied (usu. in hunger)
usecase: I felt satiated after eating a snack.

definition: adj. having practical intelligence or knowledge
usecase: My brother is not very savvy when it comes to using public transportation.

definition: adj. morally offensive, often causing damage to one’s reputation
usecase: The scandalous politician decided it was best to resign from office.

definition: v. to look down on with disdain
usecase: It’s difficult for me not to scorn those who use improper grammar.

definition: adj. paying great attention to detail
usecase: I am a scrupulous proofreader and never miss an error.

definition: v. to examine carefully and critically
usecase: The teacher scrutinized her students’ essays.

definition: v. to produce or release (a substance)
usecase: Trees secrete a sticky substance called sap.

definition: n. opinion
usecase: I am of the sentiment that you should never give out your passwords to anyone.

definition: n. a tender or moving gesture
usecase: Even though I’m not a big fan of porcelain dolls, I appreciated the sentiment.

definition: adj. so thin that light can shine through
usecase: The curtains on the window were so sheer you could clearly see inside the house.

definition: adj. easy; not complex
usecase: This math problem is so simple even a first grader can solve it.

definition: adj. undecorated
usecase: The simple beauty of the ocean is what makes it memorable.

definition: adj. ominous, evil
usecase: Medieval peasants believed sinister demons could harm humans.

definition: n. the joining of commonalities or common purposes among a group
usecase: I stood in solidarity with other female students by refusing to wear the school’s sexist uniform.

definition: adv. insufficiently, meagerly, or in a restricted manner
usecase: Due to my condition, I must eat salt sparingly.

definition: v. to release eggs
usecase: Frogs typically spawn in ponds.

definition: v. to call forth or generate
usecase: The topic spawned an ongoing debate among his family members.

definition: v. to stimulate or incite
usecase: Her bravery spurred others to act.

definition: adj. run-down, sordid, or sleazy
usecase: The squalid cabin needed a new roof and an exterminator.

definition: adj. very plain; devoid of any details or features
usecase: Looking out at the stark landscape, I felt a keen sense of isolation.

definition: adj. motionless
usecase: The ball is static.

definition: adj. changeless
usecase: Her life has been static for the past three years.

definition: adj. lower in rank
usecase: The subordinate officers work every day.

definition: n. someone lower in rank
usecase: My subordinate will check you in.

definition: v. to make dependent on or put at a lower rank
usecase: You aren’t my boss—you can’t subordinate me to the role of receptionist!

definition: adv. happening later or after something
usecase: I subsequently went home.

definition: adj. very large in amount or degree
usecase: I was shocked to find a substantial amount of money beneath the park bench.

definition: v. to strengthen with new evidence or facts
usecase: It is important for scientists to substantiate their theories whenever possible.

definition: adj. hard to detect or analyze
usecase: I detected in her expression a subtle hint of irritation.

definition: adj. enough; just meeting a requirement
usecase: These boxes should be sufficient for our move.

definition: adj. unfriendly; inclined to anger
usecase: The bartender was a surly fellow who wasn’t afraid to start a fight.

definition: v. to get on top of or overcome
usecase: They managed to surmount the language barrier by using a translation app.

definition: adj. to be vulnerable (to something)
usecase: Children are more susceptible to certain illnesses than adults are.

definition: adj. skilled at dealing with people
usecase: Her tactful attitude toward our class made her one of my favorite teachers.

definition: adj. pulled tight
usecase: The rubberband was taut and ready to be fired.

definition: adj. abundantly filled (usu. with living organisms)
usecase: Doorknobs are not as clean as they look and are often teeming with germs.

definition: n. usual mood or feelings
usecase: She had a hostile temperament, making her intimidating to most people.

definition: adj. not yet finalized
usecase: We haven’t made any official arrangements yet, but the tentative location for our wedding is Hawaii.

definition: adj. see-through; so thin that light can shine through
usecase: Stained window glass isn’t as transparent as regular window glass is.

definition: adj. truthful or easy to perceive
usecase: She was transparent about her plans to end her marriage.

definition: adj. dangerous and unstable
usecase: The journey was becoming treacherous, but they continued on regardless.

definition: adj. very large, good, or bad in degree or size
usecase: Tremendous news! You don’t have to repay your loans!

definition: adj. being everywhere at once
usecase: Cell phones are ubiquitous these days.

definition: adj. undecorated, plain
usecase: Though the dress was cheap and unadorned, it was by far her favorite one on the rack.

definition: v. to weaken or subvert (usu. gradually or secretly)
usecase: Parents should take care not to constantly undermine their children.

definition: v. to emphasize or give additional weight to
usecase: This sentence seems to underscore the overall meaning of the passage.

definition: v. to move as ripples or in a wavy pattern
usecase: Belly dancers are known for their ability to skillfully undulate their stomachs.

definition: adj. one-sided
usecase: The unilateral decision was deemed unfair by the other party involved.

definition: adj. unfair; not justified
usecase: The court’s decision is unjust—he should not go free.

definition: adj. downright, utter, total
usecase: My speech was an unmitigated disaster!

definition: adj. completely new and never having happened before; historic
usecase: The number of protestors was unprecedented.

definition: v. to make visible; to reveal
usecase: We plan to unveil our plans for the new company project on Sunday.

definition: n. desire or impulse
usecase: He had the urge to tell his parents about his acceptance to Columbia but decided against it.

definition: v. to encourage or persuade
usecase: She urged her sister to apply to Stanford.

definition: v. to prove or declare valid
usecase: Your selfish actions do not validate your feelings for me.

definition: n. ability to be done in a practical or useful way
usecase: The viability of the solution is questionable.

definition: adj. urgently necessary
usecase: It is vital that you respond by the deadline.

definition: v. to promise
usecase: My brother quickly broke his vow to never eat chocolate again.

definition: v. to prove to be reasonable
usecase: Wanting to look cool in front of your friends doesn’t warrant breaking the law.

definition: n. production of an amount
usecase: The farmer’s annual pumpkin yield exceeded 10,000.

definition: v. to give way to or surrender to
usecase: Cars turning right on red must yield to oncoming traffic.

definition: v. to produce or supply
usecase: Our experiment yielded many unique-looking vegetables.
